clinical_study.brief_title: Blood Flow Restricted Electrical Stimulation During Immobilisation
clinical_study.official_title: Investigating the Effect of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation and Blood Flow Restriction Training on Physiological Deconditioning During Unloading and Retraining

brief_summary.textblock: Following injury or surgery to a limb, it is often immobilised to allow tissue healing. Short periods of disuse cause loss of muscle size and strength and impaired mechanical properties of tendons, which leads to reduced function. Strategies to combat these deconditioning adaptations include neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), however at present its effectiveness is limited. Recent research suggests that the effects of NMES can be augmented with blood flow restriction (BFR). At present, the effect of combining these two techniques on muscle function during limb immobilisation is unknown. Furthermore, the impact of BFR training during retraining following immobilisation is unknown.

detailed_description.textblock:
Following injury or surgery to a limb, it is often immobilised to allow tissue healing. Short periods of disuse cause loss of muscle size and strength and impaired mechanical properties of tendons, which leads to reduced function. Strategies to combat these deconditioning adaptations include neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), however at present its effectiveness is limited. Recent research suggests that the effects of NMES can be augmented with blood flow restriction (BFR). At present, the effect of combining these two techniques on muscle function during limb immobilisation is unknown. Furthermore, the impact of BFR training during retraining following immobilisation is unknown.
This study will examine the effectiveness and feasibility of a neuromuscular electrical stimulation and blood flow restriction protocol during a 7 day period of immobilisation. Multiple measures across several physiological systems will be obtained.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximal isometric strength via Biodex Dynamometer
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximal isokinetic strength via Biodex Dynamometer
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle endurance via Biodex Dynamometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle morphology via 2D and 3D ultrasonography
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle VO2 via near-infrared spectroscopy
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in blood markers via venous blood samples
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pressure pain thresholds via handheld allometry
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in corticomotor excitability and inhibition, via transcranial magnetic stimulation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year

arm_group.arm_group_label: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation with blood flow restriction

intervention.intervention_name: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation with blood flow restriction
intervention.description: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation with blood flow restriction
intervention.arm_group_label: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation with blood flow restriction

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Between the age of 18-55
- Non-smoker
- No previous history of cardiovascular, respiratory or neurological problems
- Not taking anticoagulant medication
- Injury-free in the 3 months prior to scheduled participation in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Hypertension (<140/80)
- Metal work in-situ
- Blood diseases or clotting issues
- Injury or previous injury (<3 months prior to scheduled participation in the study)
- Pregnancy
